Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Vision begins with the absorption of a photon of light by the retina. It is absorbed by rhodopsin, a pigment in the retina, which consists of a retinal molecule bound to the opsin protein and is embedded in the membrane of a rod photoreceptor cell. Photons trigger the photoisomerization of the retinal molecule from the 11-cis to the all-trans form. A conformational change in opsin associated with the isomerization of retinal is what ultimately generates a visual signal by the cell. Rhodopsin has evolved to be a very reliable detector: it can respond to a million-fold range of light intensity. At the same time, it is exquisitely sensitive, detecting even a single photon. This sensitivity requires very low "dark noise" or isomerization rate when no light is present. Retinal can isomerize due to heat as well as light, and the isomerization is identical. To gain ever better night vision, animals evolved rhodopsin whose dark noise at 37Â°C is reduced to one thermal isomerization event every 420 years. This project seeks to answer a question that has puzzled scientists for decades: What is the mechanism by which rhodopsin achieves its incredibly low dark noise without compromising its sensitivity? In particular, the project will test the hypothesis that a recently discovered extensive hydrogen-bonding network in the rhodopsin molecule prevents thermal isomerization.

Visual processing has fascinated scholars for centuries and makes this project appealing for science education and outreach, as well as important for advancing the scientific understanding of the visual system. This research is at the interface of physical and biological science and will provide valuable cross-disciplinary training for students and researchers at all levels, from high school to postdoctoral. Through the established collaborations with the Community Office at Yale and Hunter College of the City University of New York, the project will provide research opportunities to pre-college and college students, many of whom are underrepresented in science and have limited exposure to frontier scientific research. Moreover, the lab members will attend the annual conference for the Society of Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science to recruit Native American and Hispanic graduate students, who are currently underrepresented in the department. Through the integration of research and education, this project will blend teaching and outreach with scientific discovery while encouraging the inclusion of underrepresented groups in the science program at Yale University.
This project is jointly supported by Molecular Systems cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Chemistry of Life Processes in the Division of Chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CAREER award allowed the PI to make impact in education and outreach and generate new knowledge in the field of vision research and beyond.

In terms of education and outreach, the PI broadened the participation of women and minorities in science, trained young scientists, and integrated research in curricula. During the funding period, the PI mentored 8 graduate students, 9 undergraduate students, one high school student, and 4 postdoctoral fellows. More than half of these students were female. Among these students and postdoctoral fellows, a female Native American, moved on to be a postdoctoral fellow at National High Magnetic Field Laboratory; a Hispanic student matriculated a graduate program at Columbia University; and an undergraduate student from Colombia was admitted to both the Harvard and Yale graduate programs. Moreover, the PI incorporated the research results into undergraduate and graduate curricula. Based on the material and teaching strategies of the graduate course, the PI and two of the graduate students published a book chapter in Teaching Bioanalytical Chemistry. Besides, the PI worked on widening the participation of minorities in science by collaborating with the Pathways to Science Program at Yale, which involved over 900 students from the inner city of New Haven. Most were minority with over 50% eligible for free or reduced-priced lunch. The PI also supported young female students by participating in their workshops and events centering on the strategies in coping with bias in career development.

In terms of research, the PI studied molecular mechanism of vision, addressing the question of how vertebrates can see in dim-light environment. The focus of the study was rhodopsin, a dim-light photoreceptor that detects light in dark environment and generates visual signals. Thermal reactions in rhodopsin can generate the same physiological response as the light-induced visual signaling process. Thus, rhodopsin’s thermal reactions set the threshold of vertebrates’ vision. Although thermal processes of rhodopsin had long been investigated, the nature of the chemical reactions behind these processes had never been clearly identified. During the funding period, the PI made a contribution to identify two chemical reactions in rhodopsin, namely thermal isomerization and hydrolysis of the protonated Schiff base. The PI’s research teams also established a kinetic model and designed kinetic experiments to measure how fast these two reactions occur, such that the threshold that limits rhodopsin’s sensitivity of light detection can be quantitatively studied. Using the model and performing the kinetic experiments, the PI studied the temperature dependence of the rates of the two thermal reactions and discovered that the rates had the strongest dependence on temperature that had ever been reported in literature. Through molecular modeling and theoretical analysis, the PI’s research team attributed the dependence to the rigid structure of rhodopsin stabilized by hydrogen bonds formed with internal water molecules, providing insight into understanding molecular mechanism of vertebrate dim-light vision.

The results of the research project had implications in several research fields. First, the studies led to a better understanding of a group of retina degenerative disease, retinitis pigmentosa. Over 100 point mutations in the rhodopsin gene can cause retinitis pigmentosa. The PI’s research team showed that some of these mutations perturb H-bonding interactions and lower thermal stability, resulting in a lower threshold for light detection, likely associated with the early symptom of retinitis pigmentosa —night blindness.
